awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Novel Representations for Distributed Control of String Networks in Vehicle Platooning and Supply Chain Management
awd_abstract_narration:
A certain class of oscillatory behaviors, popularly known as the butterfly effect or the bullwhip effect are quite habitual to large scale networks of dynamical systems, such as electrical networks, supply chains or transportation networks. They essentially describe as tiny perturbations (or fluctuations) in the functional parameters occurring in one area of the network, start to amplify while propagating through the dynamics of the network and ultimately result in extremely large deviations from the operational parameters in other parts of the network.  This undesired phenomenon is very common and difficult to avert in important practical applications. The proposal brings forth a novel mathematical description of dynamical networks introduced by the PI, which is capable of capturing simultaneously both the dynamics and the topology of a given network. Preliminary results for the case of a string of dynamical agents (vehicles platooning) showed that coupled with concepts and methods from classical control theory, this new mathematical description will be investigated for the development of practical methods for the design of distributed controllers.

For the case of networks with linear and time invariant dynamics, the distributed nature of the controller is cast as sparsity constraints on the controller left coprime factors, to be used in tandem with sparsity constraints imposed on the closed-loop maps. While delineating costs to specific nodes of the network, the constraints on the closed-loop map guarantee the tractability of the distributed, optimal controller design problem and characterize the manner in which disturbances propagate through the closed loop, thus eliminating the bullwhip effect.  The goal is to investigate the needed adaptation of the concept of internal stability of the feedback loop, which becomes necessary in the current paradigm of the distributed implementation of controllers.

por.por_cntn:
In several practical scenarios in distributed control, the large scale plant  may be represented for instance as a network of interconnected systems. The difficulty of the problem stems from constraining the feedback control law to function based only on a subset of the plant's measurements.  One of the severe limitations of existing methods  is that the overall performance of the scheme depends heavily of the size of the plant (i.e. the performance degrades as the size grows) and furthermore the "local performance" depends on the relative position within the network.

This research introduces a novel distributed control architecture for networks with linear and time invariant dynamics that is completely scalable with the size of the network and therefore is particularly well suited  for large scale systems. This feature is due to the fact that resulting feedback schemes completely avoid the exchange of internal states, i.e., plant or controller states, among sub-controllers allowing for a natural distributed feedback/feedforward formulation, while being amenable to convex formulations for controller design using norm-based costs. Additionally,  closed state-space formulas for the distributed implementation of the sub-controllers are also included. The method enables the systematic design of distributed  H∞ controllers, by imposing sparsity constraints on the controller’s coprime factors rather than on the controller's input/output map, via a convex and iterative optimization procedure with guaranteed convergence. By exploiting the inherent  robustness-oriented nature of the method,  one can compute distributed representations of the control law that otherwise may not be directly available from the plant’s nominal model. As an avenue for further research, the model predictive control pendant of the H∞ method proposed here, is susceptible to be solved via a Youla-like parameterization of all state estimators that can stabilize the plant in tandem with a given, prespecified state feedback.

When applied for instance to highway platooning, the method naturally retrieves the architecture of the celebrated Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control scheme, while unveiling a novel mechanism able to compensate for heterogeneous drive-trains, for inter-agent communications induced time delays and jitter and to gracefully reconfigure for agents merging/exiting the formation. Other envisaged applications pertain to the distributed voltage regulation in islanded microgrids (representing inverters as voltage controlled current sources) and the distributed inventory regulation in supply chains.
